comment: Git helps us organize our concurrent workflow!
Jenkins is great for continuous integration!
Test Driven Development is initially challenging, but yields efficiency with time.
Asynchrony Hive was build by an Agile development team
WebStorm is a decent IDE for Angular development, and is customizable. Ruby features are an additional upgrade.
Good documentation and widespread use made it an easy decision to choose this over EmberJS
Difficult to use and provided very little or poor documentation.
Docker is powerful, but at times lacks comprehensive documentation and support
Nginx is easy to setup in a Docker container
Protractor is a great tool for end-to-end testing, but tests can be finicky.
Selenium works well but use sparingly.
Makes deployment on JavaScript easier.
Not sure it is worth $40
RoR is easy!
PhantomJS is great for testing, but can fail with some angular syntax. Found it to be useful, but difficult to configure and work with.
Selenium Webdriver works well for E2E testing. Difficult to initially configure.
These should be done frequently to help your team continuously improve themselves.
Helps skilled testers to find deeply seeded bugs.
A nice visual way to see what is going on in your git repository.
Seems to work well. It is used by the team only because it is a dependency.
Does a good job at running our unit tests on browsers.
Simple and easy to use, read, and understand.
Makes working with CSS much more tolerable.
Difficult to work with, but a necessity to get some nice website features.
Do not really care to work with it, but it does the job.
An easy to use package manager.
An easy to use package manager.
Difficult to use and provided either very little or poor documentation.
Best source control tool ever!
I believe a lot of websites look just like everyone else’s
I believe using git on the command line is a way better
I haven't had a good experience using WebStorm, I like Atom better
I've seen projects using it, and it's pretty cool the things you can do with it.
it's one of the most popular frameworks and it has been adopted by companies such as Apple
One of the best packages manager that I've seen
Pretty easy to use and understand if you have experience using npm
Still not sure if gulp would be a better option
Not only adopt, but use branches, and tags!

My feeling about Rails is that much of what I want to do and configure seems to be difficult whenever I'm diverting from the Ruby defaults and conventions. So while it might be fine for small projects that you need to get up and running quickly, large projects that require a lot of tweaking and optimization may actually be difficult in Rails.
Absolutely needed
This tool is easy to use to examine the database and write database queries.
Time-boxed exploratory testing is a good tool to use to find edge-cases.
When your excuse for not having a retrospective is that you have too much to do, then maybe your retrospective should be about workload.
www.meetup.com/Agile-Denver/ and https://milehighagile.org/ are good Denver organizations.
Agile allowed us to deliver a quick customer demo (~3 weeks of development) using technologies new to our team.
Decentralized source control is just plain better.
Useful for a common language across more layers of the stack, but I feel like other languages have better features for making server side applications more robust.
When you have to make changes to a piece of code you've never seen before, nothing is more reassuring than seeing that it is covered by good tests.
By far the most efficient way to get good work done
Can be buggy and crash a lot but there aren't too many good alternatives other than Xvfb.
Good responsive framework but customization of UI components is not so simple and there are several alternatives out there.
Great repository provider. You can control environment specific dependencies easily and control versions/updates easily.
Makes writing css so much easier and makes your styles more concise, reusable , and compartmentalized.
Nice UI and has all of the dev tools needed built in like source control and terminal
Pretty much a necessity for any feature rich web application
Really simple to set up and has tons of options for all the now standard front end practices like minification, environment specific configurations, and unit testing.
There are definitely better tools out there.
Very cool powerful tool but it can be limiting at times. Great for environment replication.
Very easy to use and has lots of free plugins for all sorts of tools like selenium, git, nodejs, docker, and email.
Very simple and useful UI
Very straight forward and comprehensive javascript MVC framework. Also, support for synchronous vs. asynchronous execution is very simple.
Allows line-by-line commit selection in a much faster and easier way to visualize. Huge win.
Avoids CSS code duplication. @include, variables, functions - all make CSS files more compact, readable, and concise.
Sets a global gitignore that excludes dll that must be  explicitly removed for each user.
If you find a pre-existing visualization type that suits your needs, you can go from a blank page to detailed graph/chart customized with your data in under an hour.

I've used the Foundation framework countless times for responsive/mobile web projects and it's worked out very nicely. I've written my own extensions on modules, come up with class/file additions where needed, but overall it's helped me produce some great sites. Note: very similar to Bootstrap though.
Simplifies deployment of software and plays well with Git
Being able to quickly spin up and down servers and other hosted services enables experimentation that speeds development and learning.
Angular architecture facilitates the development of testable and maintainable front end web applications faster than with any other JavaScript framework I've used before.
I've gotten a lot of productivity out of bootstrap when developing responsive web apps. Can be used with SASS or LESS.
Has some great features but I feel unit testing frameworks still have a ways to go in JavaScript. I would suggest keeping it simple with Jasmine so tests don't become a huge burden to maintain.
We have having good success using CoreOS as the host OS for our docker services. It requires little maintenance and is easily configured in a declarative way (read: yaml, not bash scripts).
Simple and great opinionated web app framework. Probably best for smaller scale projects and quick prototyping needs.
Makes writing CSS maintainable. Much more powerful than writing plain CSS.
At this point, most packages are already available on npm which is significantly more useful due to direct ties to node
Having a time and a place for constructive discussion allows teams to asses and improve. It doesn't matter what your team does, retrospectives will make it better.

In game development, Exploratory Testing is the de facto standard. This is because there are often too many edge cases to think of. Assuming other types of software also don't have too many edge cases is foolhardy.

It's very good at keeping files organized into reusable components that are incredibly flexible in what they contain.  Build a react component that requires a set of svgs for instance and when compiled, the react component is included in the bundle and the svgs are added to an svg sprite.

The vast number of plugins, easy to read config files, adaptability, and documentation are all part of why this is my go to automation tool over grunt. I've used it many many times for a wide array of projects to cover the things that I don't want to do by hand.
FITE is investigating running .NET applications in Linux Docker containers using .NET Core.
in favor of gulp. They're both about the same, might as well use the one that's a bit faster. I also have had trouble getting grunt to do exactly what I want in the past,
There are a number of implementations for different languages which might be called out on their own.
See also: https://github.com/ReactiveX/RxJava

Retrofit utilizes OkHttp + Okio under the covers.  Generally used with Google's GSON library for parsing the JSON but can be configured with other libraries if required, can also run over Protobuf with the right converter library.
As a potential alternative, a team at PayPal open sourced an attempt at a framework-agnostic version of ngMock: https://github.com/krakenjs/sync-browser-mocks
Used by Retrofit, but also stands on its own.
This is a great tool to have on any project that uses asynchronous communication.
Easier to use and offers way more than iterm.
more advanced features than iTerm and great for running on servers

Glide marginally wins over Picasso for image loading + local caching - the API is virtually identical to Picasso but Glide does a better job of caching transformed images resulting in faster GUI updates, where Picasso caches the originals and must transform them each time.  Both Glide and Picasso run over OkHttp.

Great community and full featured framework to get you quickly building your app so you won't have to worry about picking many parts and figuring out how to integrate them.  See https://leanpub.com/ember-cli-101/read and https://guides.emberjs.com/
Works well and the tooling is getting better
Kubernetes sounds like a good way to run a containerized service cluster, but setup is intimidating. Google and others in the industry are behind Kubernetes.

I would not start of any new projects using Angular 1 at this point, as the javascript community has been rapidly progressing towards common patterns embraced by React and Ember. Angular 2 looks to be heading in a good direction but has been very slow to arrive.
Extremely powerful build tooling, but be careful to not do too much too quickly. It can quickly become overwhelming and hard to find your way if you jump in.
It's practically dead, use NPM
Industry standard for framework tooling. Angular 2 is adopting it for all of its build needs.
On a large project it was found that RoboGuice had memory leaks that hurt the UAT run.  Go with Dagger 2 instead.

Much of the JetBrains family of IDE products are written in Kotlin.  Gradle 3.0 (coming soon to a build near you!) will support writing your build scripts in Kotlin Script.  As an alternative language to create Android apps, its overall "footprint" (size of runtime) is relatively small compared with the alternatives.
Gradle is the standard build tool for all Android projects.  It is the natural replacement for tools like ant or maven in other settings.
Yaml based tmux session awesomeness
adopt this dude
We're starting to implement this in Ionic
Objective C? More like Objective F, amirite?
If you're doing node.js you're using npm. That's how it is. Good thing it ain't too shabby.
I'd like to see you try something else.
Makes making rest calls in an Android app easy as pie. More specifically - easy like a pie that happens to be easy to make.
It's the future.
It's the past, present and future.
Using make/Makefiles had made iOS CI easier with jenkins by allowing us to avoid plugins.

We should stop mocking the crap out of everything.  It makes it impossible to refactor and keep tests green.  It also doesn't actually prove that my software works.  It only proves that I wrote the code the way I wanted to write the code.
Don't mock by default. Mock your edges.
super useful on remote servers; good for remote pairing.  Also for development if you spend most of your time in a terminal

A really valuable tool for letting you use modules in your source javascript without having to worry about referencing dependency files or polluting the global namespace with dependency objects.  It does create a potentially very large bundled js file, however, and jquery can be a little tricky (i.e., an external dependency that adds a jquery plugin would prevent you from using a module-based jquery).

Out of the box build pipeline, out of the box test runner, cli generation of framework components with tests automatically scaffolded, a built in ORM layer for converting REST calls to local entities.
This is too vague and generic to be useful. Suggest removing it.
It isn't perfect but I have yet to find anything better for CI

I would avoid handwriting Makefiles directly for medium to large projects as there are a number of really good tools that wrap make and keep your project configuration much easier to maintain. For example, CMake
This has the description for Nginx, not ngMock

I have used Frank (www.testingwithfrank.com) which uses Cucumber to create UATs for iOS applications. It does a good job of encouraging you to write tests that are readable and can easily be translated (or taken verbatim) for a manual test script.

Agree with Isaac. I would avoid trying to write your entire frontend functional test suite with Selenium. Our team has attempted that and felt a good deal of pain. I would recommend Cucumber over Selenium in general.
I've never gotten around to learning tmux but I am a long time user of GNU screen, which is basically the same thing, and it is a gamechanger.
If I could "Adopt" this twice, I would. Oh wait, I can?
batteries-included framework which is admittedly opinionated but right most of the time.
Link is broken
This is the 21 century. Ain't nobody got time for Makefile any longer with so many alternatives out there.
Elixir looks very promising, especially when coupled with Phoenix for Web development. I am really anxious to get an excuse to use it on a project!

In the past 6+ yrs I've used it, I cannot find a single good thing to say about it. There are better alternatives out there that simply *work*. There is nothing worse than slooooooow selenium tests, that pass and fail on occasion for silly reasons, or work on my workstation but do not work on the build box some, pass on some browsers but not on others. Gross! Can we just all agree that it was a mistake a long time ago, and it's OK to admit that we were misguided in using it. Nobody will judge :)
Gulp provides really valuable work flow tools, particularly if you are transpiling ES6 or JSX. Gulp's pipe syntax is intuitive and terse.
Great when you just want a decent looking website and aren't picky about the details
but let's face it, VBScript is the future
Unless you have a specific need for extensibility via plugins (specifically OSGI plugins), the benefits of this platform outweigh the complexity
The cloud is the future and Amazon is winning the arms race. If we don't start using it more we will be behind the curve.

Mocks make it hard to refactor our code. Too often the tests know about the implementation of the method, versus just caring about the results. A side effect of mocks are having interfaces with a single implementation. Plus, people much smarter than us (Martin Fowler and Kent Beck) tell us not to use them in the way we do.

To often these sessions seem to be unfocused and turn into a gripe session. In my experience, I have not felt that much change has come from our retros. That commonly people go back to doing things the way they always have. I also feel that this could be replaced if the team itself has good dialogue on a day to day basis.
These are the tests that prove your system actually works. Why would you not do this?
It's the top of the testing pyramid (http://martinfowler.com/bliki/TestPyramid.html). We should always do this.
I would tend to agree with Ryan on this one.
It doesn't scale :-)
The extra indirection added from the Gherkin doesn't make up for its value. No one who cannot read code is going to read them anyway. Just write them in code.
Vim users are asked to help poor children in Kibaale, located in the south of Uganda.
powerful with tmux combination.  throw you mouse away
reliable! Has debugging, integrates nicely with gulp.
The interfaces between objects should be values or functions, not objects, whenever possible. The exact specifics greatly depend on the language under consideration.
Though its interface is awkward at best, it does its job fantastically well.
No annoying licensing or registrations, and it works in the same window as your git command line.
Strictly better than any other existing way to test the UI of iOS applications
Despite its (many, many) flaws, it is still the best way to write apps for Apple's platforms.

Superseded by Swift, which is a better language in every way. All Objective-C written now on new work is technical debt.  When maintaining codebases with primarily Objective-C code, however, Objective-C is probably the better choice so as to not introduce risk to legacy applications.
My preference is for Mocha but this is growing on me. Maybe in the future I'll adopt.
Although I'd love to find a better tool with a similar feature set, this tool is the best I've seen (sadly).
Angular is hitting a transition point between 1 and 2.

Asynchrony has been using mediawiki since 2007 for internal and delivery-team communication and collaboration and continues to be a major source of information and widely-accessible collaboration space.

I can't believe all mocking is bad.  I've seen it overdone, but with little guidance on how to do it better.  I for one would like to see someone that is anti-mocks step through a recent code base and help figure out how to write the same tests without mocks.

These serve as a way to step back and reflect.  If your team has communication / trust problems and isn't focused on continuous improvement, they don't provide much value.  When the team is healthy, they do provide value.  Team size may affect the quality of these meetings.
Great for collaborating on information, poor for information discovery unless well maintained and curated.

I would like to see more teams try this.  Every team I've been on that has done it has been excellent once the team got in the groove.  I've seen teams struggle with this when they are not efficient in switching or haven't found a good way to slice up work.
It would require running Rubinus to achieve its full potential, but could still offer benefits on MRI ruby. Would need to compare to something like Thin.
Makefile should be an implementation detail, not something you have to ever see or edit.

There are still a lot of unknowns about how helpful the HIVE can be in everyday work, or for us as a company. However, the underlying idea of a Technology Radar has borne fruit for other firms, so we should see how it can work for us.
Auto-installed global gitignore has caused our team issues numerous times
Works well for some groups but not for others in my experience
I would like to see some good examples of TDD without mocking

It's not for every circumstance, but it's still an incredibly powerful little editor. Its ubiquity is a feature, as even when other, better editors might not be available, vim will be. Works best if set up with plugins and other custom things.
Leak Canary has a lot of false positives, especially with apps using WebView, that can make it difficult to identify real memory leaks.
Load testing is something every team should be doing up-front. This tool's nice b/c your tests are in code (Scala) instead of configuration.
Still the best way to set up command-line tasks with dependencies on each other. Nothing else comes close in capability, stability, and editability.
Of course this is adopt - do we even need C# on the tech radar?
It looks like it could be better than Unicorn. Need to see someone using it in a production settings and see performance under load.
It's just a fad...
It's like NPM... but less... and losing support.

It's an abstraction around tests solely for the purpose of having the business be able to read (and possibly write) them. No client I've worked with actually wanted to write/maintain these. It's always a bit of a headache. Trying to make reusable steps for human readable/machine executable paragraphs is a pain.
Still the most straight forward build tool I've seen/worked with. Can get complicated with larger projects but there are tools (aclocal, autoconf, etc.) to help manage that. Very mature product.

Mocking often makes tests much more readable and easier to write, while in some cases it's vital for stopping real services from being run while being able to test code execution.  While not perfect for every situation, mocking is a definite tool you should have in your testing toolbag.
Dagger 1 uses reflection to generate the ObjectGraph in some cases. Proguarding becomes impossible with Dagger 1. Use Dagger 2 instead.
Both Picasso and Glide are viable image loading libraries.
Bring some useful Java 8 features (e.g. lambdas) to Android. Really useful when used in conjunction with RxJava.

Otto is now deprecated in favor of RxJava + RxAndroid. If not wanting to write a custom event bus using RxJava + RxAndroid, Greenrobot's EventBus should be used. Eventbus is superior [overall](https://github.com/greenrobot/EventBus/blob/master/COMPARISON.md).
Only to be used if RxJava + RxAndroid is not used in the project.
Can I really rate this twice?
Do NOT use JodaTime proper in Android apps. Reasons here. https://github.com/dlew/joda-time-android
Generates very large files. Config can be confusing.
WAH. Can't edit…   However, can be super powerful, when built up correctly
http://blog.thecodewhisperer.com/permalink/integrated-tests-are-a-scam
Very fast, very easy to setup. Supported in JSBin, CodePen and others. Has an online REPL!  http://babeljs.io/repl/
On android keep an eye out for missed events.

There is a large impact on dexcount when used on Android. There also can be issues related to injection performance when dependency injection is heavily used.Otherwise, it is a fine framework that works as described.
I tend to dislike dependency injection frameworks, but roboguice works alright.
The Internet uses HTML; it is imperative that we adopt this technology. :)
This is a neat hack. Hopefully long term it is completely replaced with the Jack compiler.

This highly depends on the kind of team you have.  If you don't have enough control over your stories and end up with large stories, it can be difficult to explain what's going on in the code you've written before the next pair switch.  If you can properly slice up your work though, feel free to feel it out.
The most important of Agile practices..
A great way to spin up a simple web project and quickly integrate it with other high quality, production ready frameworks.

This tool seems to be highly distracting during work hours after its initial release, but maybe it will help us out.  Also, it seems to have bugs.  Ratings may not be averaged right and you can double post here rather than editing old posts.  This technology is very much in beta.
If it is really your best option..
Wicked fast and easy to maintain. Integrates well into Spring based projects on the Java side.
This is a very popular framework in the dev ops world right now. Might be worth considering for certain use cases.

I hate select2 with the burning hate of a thousand suns. Every time we have had to deal with it, it has turned a story that should have taken one hour into a story that takes one or multiple days. However, I am unaware of any decent alternative. Maybe "chosen" (https://harvesthq.github.io/chosen/)?
Avoid except for in these special circumstances: 1) Sharing data between applications on Android 2) SyncAdapters -- a stub content provider works 3) Infinite lists in android
