Am I the only developer who finds acceptance tests written in code extremely difficult to read? The Selenium tests on my current project are a nightmare, and the helper code we had to write to support them were no less of a headache to write than it would have been using Cucumber.

Major upgrade to test suite management in Mingle.  TestLink allows you to keep separate versions of the test suite per app version and keep results for every round of testing.  QAs can divide of the test suite for assignment to team members.  You can include dependencies and use keywords to note other apps/services that are involved in the test.  Yes, it has its quirks but it's free.

I don't get the impression that select2 was created with testability in mind. Largely because of this, I've seen a lot of JavaScript code that does a very poor job of testing their usages of select2. I'd prefer to avoid it when possible.
I've loved using Autofac since I started doing some .NET stuff, and I can't imagine life without it now.

We had some crazy non-deterministic behavior (not the same problems as Paul Hawke) that couldn't be figured out by three to five engineers over the course of months, but frequently killed the build. We had to switch to Dagger 2 after it started affecting the client too.
Gets the job done
Scaling really is an issue. Be careful.
You don't have to go rewrite the world in Swift. You may do a client a disservice to blindly tell them to rewrite a codebase.
Deep concerns about meaningfully testing streams. No real answers there yet.
I've seen it tried several times, don't know that I ever saw it work well.
If you use mocks poorly you will not derive value from them. They should be used against very clean and minimal interfaces. If you refactor and it breaks your mock tests, you're doing it wrong.
Swift is the future but ObjC is the past and there's a heck of a lot of the past.  Any Apple developer would still be advised to know ObjC .

I see the potential in a tool like this to make up for the dispersion of knowledge across the organization.  As a 5+ year veteran, I've collected this information over time and know who to talk to for help / guidance in a given technology.  However that knowledge base can quickly get out of date and is impossible for people with less time at the company to recreate and leverage quickly.
I'm for every developer using the tool that works best for them.  I personally don't use a Mac, but that's because I haven't had a use for it I can't get on other platforms.
To me this is the best option for windows based applications for writing "click" tests for front-end UATs.  I'd be open to others, but haven't had a chance to use them.
Complicated and verbose, but the best available if you want to avoid reflection in Android and still have dependency injection.
And upgrade to Jenkins 2! It's an amazing leap forward.
Used in connection with Jenkins 2 pipeline-as-code, Docker containers can smooth out your build pipeline a great deal.

Rating "Avoid" because I think mocking frameworks are overused, often with little concern regarding the ~value~ of the types of tests that they tend to produce. Our tests should be less concerned with the actual implementation and more concerned with the overall behavior of the system. The value of the test should be two-fold: to ensure the behavior of the system is as we expect and to document the expected behavior of the system for future reference.
Syntax is easy and clean.  Simple and straightforward.  I would use it again.
The power of a full POSIX dev environment, with a user-friendly interface. Hands down better than anything else.
Good Mocking can help you focus on what you need to care about in the moment. It should be noted that you need an additional integration or user acceptance layer that is not mocked.
Agile principle #12
If you are not slicing stories small enough, hour pair switches will cause pain. But remember to focus on fixing the pain.

Nicely integrated with Xcode, but lack of documentation and ability to grab real views and view controllers leaves this a little limited when compared to KIF.  For example: Can't test the background color of a view.  Hopefully will improve.
Many things to improve, but really we don't have a choice.

My experience with mob programming has been mixed. It seems like a decent tool for transferring ideas and knowledge. However, I have found that very small stories and rigid rules are paramount to a successful mob programming exercise. In addition, mob programming in my experience has been a disaster for learning new technologies. I have found it much easier for each team member to learn on their own and have turn around sessions to transfer knowledge.

I think the url and the Description given is a bit inflammatory.  Mocking takes the pain out of creating a stub for the repository a hundred times.  If you are following SOLID then mocking wont hurt you.  10/10 would recommend.

Our Intern team, working on the advocacy project, has successfully implemented this. We found that the knowledge sharing and the exposure to more aspects of the project has increased quite a bit. We mitigated the pain by simply having a mini stand up on the hour, every hour to quickly update the rest of the team on new or solved problems. Afterwards, we determine who rotates and who stays.

I agree with everything everyone has said here, and yet the votes range from Avoid to Adopt and everything in between. The "Avoid" votes puzzle me; they basically say you shouldn't use mocking inappropriately.  Well, of course you shouldn't use *anything* inappropriately. But should you avoid mocking entirely? TDD can be done poorly; should we rate that as "Avoid"? Same goes for Agile, pair programming, etc.

For a large project after getting over the hump of setting it up and getting tests running in a way that is easily modified and maintainable it is great. For a smaller project using a dependency injection pattern and factories is preferable.

Avoid if we go by the description of Mocking in Hive (look to the left): "Mock everything. Treat everything as a black box. Even that class I just wrote."  We can't blindly mock everything without writing good higher level tests that would fail first (BDD, Functional, whatever you wanna call them).  Without them mocking will fail to expose the integration of various pieces of the software.  Hence, Avoid "mocking everything".
Docker is nice, but sometimes your project doesn't need it.
A declarative tool which which is compatible with many popular cloud and IaaS platforms.
May be very good for your project and has an amazing type system. A lot of the standard library patterns are based on category theory, which is kind of weird, but super fun.

While there are certainly situations where Mocking should be avoided like integration tests, mocking is a powerful way to inject known behavior into dependencies in order to more easily unit test classes that are composed
a must-have for building Ember apps

Does not work at all for bindings across modules. See issue https://github.com/JakeWharton/butterknife/issues/2. This may be fixed in the next version. Care should be used to access if these limitations will be involved in target project.
This is such a firmly established practice that I'm not sure it bears mentioning here.

Excellent IO efficiency without callback gymnastics, but lacking great testing and mocking frameworks making Asynchrony style development difficult. This may be a good choice for IOT frameworks that need to execute in natively. Lack of a good build pipeline is also concerning.

Roboguice can be slow and cause memory issues on medium to large size projects. Guice is a great dependency injection framework for non-mobile use cases. I would suggest editing this entry to only include Roboguice. I have already created a separate item for standard Guice
Replaced by RxAndroid per the library creator.
Defacto android rest client library.

It has high overhead for avoiding memory leaks especially when used in fragments and views. It is just another thing to think about when we can focus energy on more important problems than view binding. Furthermore the onClick/onTouch/etc nicety has a caveat that it locks you into a specific implementation of those that is not stock, and there seems to be no easy way to override the default implementation.

this should not be viewed as a solution to any problem but rather a byproduct of doing so many other things first.  Small stories, evenly matched and experienced developers, low overhead/waste, well defined acceptance criteria, sane strategy for dealing with tech debt, etc.  Lots of teams suggest this to solve some problem and fail at it unless this is a catalyst for the changes mentioned above.
Fantastic program with a great deal of flexibility depending on the need.

I recommend most teams do this for at least a month.  About the one month mark every team I've been on has clicked and been able to do it without problem.  Some teams then switch back to 2 hour pair switches, but it has removed the excuse that switching is the source of problems.  I said adopt because all teams can do it, and its worth doing as a learning exercise.  Then switch to a pairing schedule that works for the project.

Have them, but if no one has any idea of how to improve end them quickly.   ALSO:  If they turn into complaiining about things that cannot be changed then commit to learning to live with it.  Keep these effective and short and they will serve you well.

Mobbing is a great tool when it is called for.  Scenarios I found the mob to be helpful is when there is a significant design decision about to be made that will set the precedent for the future of the entire project, and/or when it is important for all of the team members to have a deep understanding of the card being worked on.
Is this Angular 1 or 2?
A great framework that allows rapid prototyping. Scaling issues continue to be addressed, however it is important to be aware of lurking dangers.
Truly powerful and configurable editor for almost any language. Can be extended to allow for flawless remote pairing.
Better to start using Swift at this point.

This tends to be the last thing we prioritize when starting a project, but it should start being one of the first things we do or else we'll never do it. Depending on the technology, the frameworks could be better. Developers should take responsibility for writing these tests with or without their stakeholders.  Note: I'm often a hypocrite about this.

I think we should being doing more integration testing, but I don't personally have a good grasp on how to interface with the edges of a system when writing integration tests.  They're generally more useful for finding bugs than unit tests, but also harder to maintain, and finding the right balance is tough.
It is simple and straightforward, but has an extreme design philosophy of independent tests which leads to not having before/after each or all.  This causes difficulty in test setup.
Bundler is magic and works really well. If you're doing any substantial work in Ruby, it'll probably make managing your dependencies way easier.

If you're interested in managing your front-end dependencies separately from you backend dependencies, bower is pretty great. I don't get the impression that bower was ever meant to do anything except for managing your runtime JavaScript deps.
Heavy on conventions and magic that may change from one version to the next.

Mocking can and frequently does create a false confidence in code and becomes a crutch that discourages early integration. "Mocking Everything" is dangerous.  Mocking can be useful but only when protected by higher level BDD or automated integration tests. If mocking to avoid the pain of integration it can be very damaging and hides the real problems.
We used it on a project for significant markdown collaboration across platforms and it worked well with several good markdown extensions.
i love this language
Never start with this approach.  Use only when conditions demand it.  You know, otherwise, YAGNI.  But it's more than that.  The pain will outweigh any possible benefits if you do it the wrong way.
Worked well, but felt like there were some tricky points in testing, and that a lot of magic was flung around while using it.
Worked well and was fairly fun.  Ran into some troubles with Node not having any atomic structures built in at all.  Expect to pair up with a database if you have a stateful, persistent system.
NPM is fit for its purpose.  Haven't tried alternatives.
Works well enough; haven't tried alternatives, which may be useful to explore.
Good for fast POCs, but creating any kind of HTML/CSS layout seems to be cumbersome and overly layered in the DOM.  Also, modals don't behave nicely with regard to scope and focus.

I've seen this done badly in multiple ways: split out too much too soon or neglected when it should have been done. Failure of implementation does not mean that the practice is faulty but that we have more to learn about it. I definitely want to see more teams doing this and getting better at it.

We initially installed it because we needed access to a Twitter feed and are too lazy to sign up for an API key, but after adding Crashlytics, doing a few deployment to Testflight from the command line, and automating app store screenshots we were sold. It might not be right for all customers, but if you're doing anything that touches the app store I would make sure you incorporate at least some parts of this before your first release.

I've felt I've only see Microservices that end up in the #2 camp http://martinfowler.com/bliki/MonolithFirst.html . There are so many things that no ones talks about when they talk about Microservices: deployment, versioning, logging, debugging, starting, stopping, authentication, authorization, scaling. ...all those things are terrible without lots of work.

I'm hesitant to flat out say avoid.  If you don't make devops and versoning first class citizens you will accrue so much technical debt so fast that any perceived value gained by using micro services is out weighed by the tech debt related to package, install, deploy, configure, troubleshoot, etc.  There is a reason why Fowler's diagram has not one but TWO dragons between you and microservices :^)
Express was very useful and fairly lightweight.  Haven't tried alternatives.
I quite like Jasmine. If you enjoy Rspec, you'll feel quite at home here. It also has some nice and idiomatic ways of verifying that asynchronous behavior can be verified well.
Excellent IOC container with good facilities for type discovery, modules, even proxies and decorators.  Simple to get started with and powerful if you need it.

Of all the practices/tools I've seen used at Async, this is the most abused. Most of the founders of XP even avoid this practice as much as possible. Use as a last resort for code that's easier to maintain and tests that provide value instead of just getting in your way.
Haven't seen anything that handles autocomplete well with Javascript yet. But this is a nice tool for quickly writing code and running tests.
Maybe not ideal for bigger projects with complex service needs or lots of users, but for something small of experimental Firebase is perfect!
I love c# so much
Simple, but useful editor with a growing list of plugins.  I specifically used it for markdown editing and it worked better than a number of other editors we tried.

We have a brief conversation on the hour to determine if we want to pair switch.  We usually end up pair switching every 1-2 hours.  Keep in mind that if frequent pair switching is painful, it's probably related to some other factor and not the pair switching itself.
This is a great article on the benefits of leveraging Python for enterprise projects:  https://www.paypal-engineering.com/2014/12/10/10-myths-of-enterprise-python/

To this day, if you want a fast, cross-platform editor, with many existing extensions and a robust community on the web to get you working quickly, it's certainly worth a look. Note:  this post is not intended to be a flame war with our other Hive entry (https://hive.asynchrony.com/#?technology=vim).

I disagree somewhat with the below comments. I think micro services can be a very successful architecture choice. Look at Yelp! https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=49_5lwGtkmo  With that said, I think a lot of the pain descried in various blogs, comes from plain inexperience. I think the misuse of YAGNI is the enemy of any well thought out architecture, which is necessary for micro services.
A great general-purpose programming language

Let me start by saying that this is not for the faint of heart. In my ~9 years at ASY, my favorite project was running on a 1 hour pair switch rule. It was glorious!! The team was comprised from highly skilled developers, an awesome Q/A that was able to keep up with the pace, we minimized the cost of context switching down to an art (less than 2 minutes), and about a month into it nobody could think going back to anything longer than that.

Adopt as a last resort when there is no other way to unit test something. For example Mock an email or repository class with a stable interface.  Testing whether a function was called is not a very valuable test in most cases.
Quite a pain to use sometimes, but I am not sure if there is anything better for scripting in a Windows environment.
Feels like a syntactical 'best of', if a little dense at first. Seems and claims to run quickly and deploy easily.
Great that it compiles down to machine code on multiple platforms at once.  Primarily useful as a systems level developmentl language.
My understanding is most people are using Spark now.

Like a lot of languages out there, Python definitely has a philosophy that you can either get on board with, or spend your whole time fighting. You will not enjoy python programming if you try to approach it with anything other than the Python mindset. That said, there are a number a great features available that really elevate the language above its deceptively simple basics. Python also has an active and responsive developer community that is quick to accept bugfix patches.
PowerShell is an ugly and cumbersome way to string together a few commands.  It's brutal.  Bash is coming to Windows so...

Python is very versatile, has tons of support and libraries, and makes it fairly trivial to automate certain tasks.  However, it comes with caveats.  Like ruby, it is not the most performant tool out of the box, but comes with the option of compiling scripts for additional speed.  In addition, Python can get cumbersome if the project hits a certain size, in which a nice IDE would be a good way to mitigate that.  I don't know how well a Python/Django stack would stand up to our existing projects.

If you are just starting out, take a minute and setup IntelliJ or Eclipse so you have syntax complete.  It will also alert you to the subtle differences of curried-types, which are oh-so important in Scala.

PowerShell is excellent even if its syntax is sort of weird. As a person who has spent a great deal of time doing shell scripting in Perl and Bash, I have found that when I am in a Windows environment, I am most productive in PowerShell. Especially in later versions of PowerShell, there are a lot of 'batteries included' especially in terms of useful tools such as Invoke-RestMethod, which supports things like Windows Authentication. Very useful and worth learning.
Solid mobile backend. Similar to Parse, but does even more. Great analytics. Very new to market, so some of the iOS documentation is a bit sparse compared to that of Android's.
Quick to get things going, enough support to run them in prod. Bottle is a great web framework (usually simpler than Flask). Scaling via workers/WSGI takes some getting used to

I think there is bad that can come if done too early or done poorly (like anything), but if you do them right they make life easier when it comes to separation of concerns.  If you find yourself touching multiple microservices to implement a story / feature, you're probably doing it wrong.

Just like any other tool, the person operating it needs to be, at a minimum aware, of its abilities and proper usage. It’s unfair to blame the tool because of either inexperienced developers or myopic views of architecture in general.

Adopt, no questions asked. Of course, just like with everything else in life, common sense should be infused. I'm sure whoever picked "Mock everything. Treat everything as a black box. Even that class I just wrote" as description, is trolling us or wants to have fun with people's reactions. Just like a knife, that can hurt or even kill someone, it should be used appropriately. One should not hastily ban all kitchen knives because someone cut their fingers once...

With a larger suite of test cases (for an older project) it gets increasingly difficult to update on the fly. Maintenance is rough, but I agree that it's the best for what it does - locally hosted test case management.
It wasn't great the last time I used it, but it's pretty handy in many situations on Windows.
Nice programming language. Decent test support. Good for a multitude of applications.

I actually enjoy it better than Ruby. We had a project that was almost exclusively Python and it was one of my favorite projects I've been on. Mature language. Good community support. And I'm a fan of significant whitespace. Good for scripting as well as larger applications.

Once I realized it wasn't Bash but it's own thing, it was kinda cool. A lot of niceties built in for autocomplete and usage docs. Not my favorite scripting language but it has it's place. If you're on a .NET project, use Powershell. If you're not, don't. :D

Depending on what you're doing, Python can be more suited to needs than Ruby. Python has many great Data Science libraries such as Pandas numPy, etc. Django and Flask are two good web frameworks to check out.
If you're on Windows, use Powershell.  Its a powerful scripting tool with the ability to do all the operating system things you'd want to automate in Windows.

Coming from expertise in other shells, PowerShell can initially be somewhat of a "what in the world."  When you understand the fact that the .NET framework is at your disposal, and that now it's ported to macOS and Linux, it definitely is worth leveraging as appropriate.

I spent years developing on windows using cygwin's bash as my primary shell. A lot of that time was devoted to fighting issues with bash on cygwin on windows. Too many layers pretending to be what they're not. Once I realized what Powershell really was, I was on board immediately. I don't always use a shell on windows, but when I do I use Powershell.
Python is my go-to scripting language for anything more complex than "pipe the output of one program into another". I've never used it for large-scale applications but others have with success.

Definitely worth learning if you are going to be doing any Windows development. I have my complaints about it (not a fan of the super verbose command names, for example) but it also has some really killer features, like being truly object-oriented, being able to use .NET assemblies, and built-in JSON and XML support. That last one makes it my favorite command-line tool for testing REST APIs (sorry curl)
You have to approach some problems a little differently but it really leads to clear code.

Powershell is an OK tool for automating Windows Domain tasks (like user management, admin tasks, install/automation).  Most of those things are accessed through the ADSI, which is a different tool altogether, making the true power of Powershell somewhat difficult to attain.  I would not recommend powershell for things you would use BASH for.

If doing something for windows, it's great.  The problem with other shells on Windows is they require downloading / installing / config.  Powershell comes by default.  I've noticed some issues with older versions that make me push for the latest when automating things, but otherwise it's pretty powerful for interacting with the OS and the tools that come along with .net development.

My go-to general-purpose language. Has rich libraries for scientific applications & nice API for string manipulation (have used for NLP and Machine Learning projects). Have also had positive experience using it with Flask for web applications. Great for everyday scripting / automation (e.g. Raspberry Pi development).
Avoid if possible. Though, due to the tremendous amount of Obj-C code around, developers should definitely still be fluent enough to understand and modify existing code.
Writing vanilla HTML has never been so 90s.
HAML works well with rails, and also on its own. Much cleaner than raw HTML, and has some nice shortcuts that assist with angular attributes.
Martin Folwer really highlights the needs and care that a microservice architecture requires.  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wgdBVIX9ifA

Microservice-based architectures offers scalability at the cost of complexity. This is a trade-off that should be considered with extreme due diligence. This is because, as others have said, the complexity that comes along with distributed computing is not trivial.  With that being said, when it comes to microservice-based architectures, I tend to agree with DHH and Martin Fowler (https://m.signalvnoise.com/the-majestic-monolith-29166d022228 and http://martinfowler.com/bliki/Monolith).
Works consistently and is installed on most machines by default.

This seems like a smart approach that I think we should be attempting more. It's a different workflow than we typically adopt, but seems like it would reduce merge complexity and allow more robust testing in larger and more complex environments.
Built on the Elixir language, this appears to be the next generation of ruby on rails.

My code seem continues to work even when I update to a new version.  Even though version management tools exist for this technology I have not had a need to use them.  This is a sign of a great technology.  Downloading packages through npm install is super easy and makes using an assortment of packages more feasible than ever.
We just discovered it has a bug where large numbers were being rounded.  Be warned.  Double check your results with this.

Great community and full featured framework to get you quickly building your app so you won't have to worry about picking many parts and figuring out how to integrate them. See https://leanpub.com/ember-cli-101/read and https://guides.emberjs.com/

Great community and full featured framework to get you quickly building your app so you won't have to worry about picking many parts and figuring out how to integrate them. See https://leanpub.com/ember-cli-101/read and https://guides.emberjs.com/  Strongly follows semve. Clear warnings and guidance are given as things are deprecated and the framework moves forward.

Good tool for what it is good at. If you write the data in the way it is intended to be read, then this can be a great tool. Joining data is painful. Writes are really slow. Know its limitations and its strengths.
It double posted my comment.

I worked on several projects that used Dagger and it worked great.  Proguard is completely possible.  You just need to put the correct rules in to retain the portions of the ObjectGraph that use reflection.  I think most people are moving to Dagger 2, but if you are on a project that uses Dagger 1, theres no good reason to rewrite it.
Objective-C will be around for a long time to come.  But if you are starting a new iOS project, it makes sense to start it in Swift.
It seems like something that might make your life easier until you really start using it and getting burned by it badly.

I've used Mongo on a few projects, here and elsewhere. I would not recommend it. There are very few cases where its flexibility outweighs its drawbacks (e.g. losing data). SQL is fast, works, feature rich these days, and it works...like 100% of the time.

I wasn't don't type. Hive needs to _not_ submit on enter in a text area.   You can make your life even more painful if you choose Mongo to just pretend its a relational database. If you have relations, embed them in a document, or just use one of those relational database.
Good training wheels with git, but once you understand git more, command-line tools like tig fill in the visual gaps the git command line itself lacks.
Works best if you have six fingers on your right hand.
I absolutely love Haproxy. It's easy to configure and is very well documented.
While languages like C# and Java have made progress in being more efficient, they still can't match the portability and performance that running C++ allows.
react-redux is a great way to manage state in a react application.
Powerful, quick, distributed key store. Query language takes some getting used to coming from SQL. Data is stored in JSON releated BSON format, which makes this pair well with Node.js.
Mongo is good as a document-oriented database, but always be VERY mindful when choosing a document-oriented database: Most businesses have structured relational data.

I worked on a few projects using MongoDB over the course of a year.  It is very convenient at first for rapidly developing an app, but there quickly comes a point where it is a liability.  There are a lot of articles online detailing the drawbacks of using MongoDB that you can find.  We definitely regretted using MongoDB as soon as non-trivial usages were required.

When using Mongo for web development, you get the power to write javascript and JSOn throughout the entire stack. The MEAN stack(Mongo, Express, Angular, Node) is popular in full stack web development currently for a reason, as it allows people to come in and pick up the code base extremely fast because there's no translation of code syntax from front end through to backend. See http://www.programmableweb.com/news/what-mean-stack-and-why-it-better-lamp/analysis/2015/12/22 for more details.

There were a couple projects at the startup I worked at that used MongoDB.  After those initial experiments, my take and that of others on the team was to avoid this database platform at all costs.  When you compare it against another NoSQL competitor like Riak or Cassandra, it isn't a great choice.  Most larger companies that need something like a "document" store such as Square, Uber, Pinterest, etc. just post JSON blobs to MySQL.  It's really a better way to do this sort of thing.
Many larger bay-area companies (e.g., Facebook, Airbnb, etc) use R Studio for data analysis.
Command line tools are always worth having around.

Consider if your data is unstructured and/or flexible, where horizontal scalability is likely very important and your app is using Javascript.  Think in terms of a scalable JSON data store thats less expensive than scaling RDBMS.  Be very careful though - not for highly structured data where concurrency and consistency are important (most business apps): Stick with an RDBMS.  Be sure to research and understand benefits and drawbacks, plus alternatives such as storing JSON in an RDBMS.
Straight forward JS. Not much ceremony, nothing special to learn beyond the language.

Hadoop is the de facto open source big data solution. We will need to understand it as we move forward into the IoT world. Any large organization can benefit hugely from using big data correctly, so this is where the new work in IT will come from going forward. Luckily, we have a dedicated group in WWT making steady progress in using this technology.
Despite being superseded by Swift, it's still a rock-solid language that is reasonable to use for development due to the instability of Swift presently.
Emacs does everything. I wrote this post in the emacs web wowser.
I used Essbase some time ago. Back when it was Hyperion Essbase. It met our needs at the time but I cannot give an accurate assessment of the current version.
I would certainly not start any new projects with Angular 1.
React is simple and modular. It does not try to be all things to all people. It also has good documentation.
This greatly simplifies asynchronous processes in react-redux applications. It is much better than redux-thunk. It makes asynchronous code as simple as synchronous code.
Angular one should not be used for a new project.
Even though Swift 3 has shipped, this seems a viable option given that the tooling around Swift is still immature.
Fast search engine and relatively easy to pick up. Only drawback is the client API's do not seem to be fully fleshed out.
Easy to install and use. Agent-less setup makes it a breeze to get started.
Eclipse complicates programming unnecessarily.
Having a single store worked better on the project I used react-redux on.  Seems like it cut out some boilerplate.

My code is so much more concise and correct using functional languages, and my thinking has shifted towards the actual data transformations I'm making rather than the procedures my code needs to make. Clojure has very good Java interop, so you can very easily plug Clojure into a Java codebase.
Java has ubiquitous adoption in the industry, and generally has enough flexibility to lend itself well to various different kinds of projects. That. And Android. :-)
I started working a little bit with .Net core on Mac OSX. Just the sheer fact that I can write C# code on a Mac makes this worth trying out.
Swift 3 has great support for functional programming, allowing devs to use very terse closure syntax for chaining filter, map, and reduce operations.
Don't really like it so far, seems super bloated and clunky. Will revisit after a few weeks since we're using it on a project at the moment.

Regarding Spark Streaming, also see the IoT Platform R&D page here https://gitlab.asynchrony.com/proj-1301/iot-platform-research-and-development/wikis/research-big-data-by-function-real-time-processing-spark-streaming

As a recent convert from Vim to Emacs (with evil mode) I have to admit, I'm liking emacs, with http://spacemacs.org, a lot more than I Vim. It's much easier to discover. It's already evicted my Vim finger memory for certain things and become my full time editor for everything.
I feel like there are better free options available in 2016.
Very handy for native apps. Makes things like MonkeyRunner throw a fit though.
Seems like they've made strides to improve the gaps in functionality recently. We've moved toward firebase for our current project.
This is great for .NET MVC or WebAPI.  Breeze to setup and stable (although there's been some issues with point releases in the past)
Using this for Angular2 bootstrap components is clean and haven't seen any issues.
Clean syntax and large number of 3rd party libraries for doing various things.
Like the syntax and ease of use.  Tooling is getting better, but still requires more knowledge to get going than plain javascript

Think of a modern database like Mongo or NoSQL.  Now think of the opposite - that’s 4D.  Its old and heavy.   It’s highly extensible which can also be its downfall since customizations cause troubles with upgrades.    It can have issues with large numbers of concurrent users in an Enterprise environment.   Certainly wouldn’t recommend for building new software.  If a client needs to migrate away from it, find out how much they've customized it and build that into your game plan.
New projects should prefer something like react/redux or angular 2.
Our team (Matthew M, Ben P, myself) has been using Protractor for 1 month with Angular2 and have used it to create all e2e test for our project successfully.

Though I'm new to the syntax it seems clean to do end to end testing in browsers with a javascript based tool.  Under the hood it uses selenium so the normal issues with a tool like that aren't magically solved, but I can't see any value in choosing a C# wrapper around selenium vs a JS one like protractor.  It does have one issue that we haven't figured out which is it can't be run from Visual Studio
It's the best. What else are you going to use?
It's still really good. I recommend it.
I do love it a lot.
Flash builder is a great way to easily build powerful flash applications. However, flash support is not long for this world so new flash development should be avoided.
I would recommend trying Protractor for e2e tests within Angular2 since it has a lot of built in capabilities for using Selenium.
Worked with this in .NET and consumed by angular 2 in typescript.  Saved a lot of time.
Tools works well for collaboration & visualization. Integration with JIRA was worthless - caused duplication of work effort. We used for story mapping.
Both the Hive and UMB teams in Denver have been using this since late 2016.  It's still missing some features, but we like the features it currently has.
Azure is very tied to Microsoft's products. As such you can get up and running very quickly. But if you don't fit the exact mold, or need more flexibility AWS is better.

The implementation of TFS that I have been using is enterprise wide. The way it was set up limits teams from being able to determine some of their own processes and forces the entire organization toward the same flow. This may very well be a problem of how the tool was implemented and not the tool itself, which is why I place this in Hold. Beyond that, the interface seems clunky and very heavy handed.
Nice interface as far as usability for remote retros. Downside is the pricing - I think there are other tools that accomplish the same goal without the cost.

Similar set of services to AWS. The APIs for interacting with services were reasonably designed, in some cases even well designed. The effort in writing simple apps to trigger new instances to startup and shutdown was minimal, but we did run into cases where building their SDK required a newer compiler (probably no longer an issue). The web console felt very Microsofty--a slick layer on top of a system that was sluggish for no good reason--but I can't honestly say it was worse than AWS's.

The RAII pattern in C++ allows for direct control of resources like files and sockets in a very non-verbose manner without interrupting flow control. This is my personal favorite feature of the language.

A little easier to use than AWS, but with a few quirks. On several occasions I have had the portal stop responding and the only thing to do was wait until the next day when it resolved itself. See https://goo.gl/6WFFhY and https://goo.gl/EJT32r . This makes azure feel a little beta to me.
Frequently breaks whenever dependent packages are updated due to fuzzy version matching.

Kendo UI does have a very large set of UI controls but have found they can slow down the UI considerably. Also if you need the controls to do anything different than what they come with, even if Telerik says they are extensible, they are not easily extensible. Themes can be really difficult to implement as well, but when you get them working they are very nice.

I've used Azure for hosting 5 of my websites for the past 4 years. It's been very solid as I've used the same single VM instance this whole time. Early on I also experimented with Azure tables (NoSQL) and SQL Azure. At the time those products felt very much like beta software but I understand they've improved drastically. Every Azure product I've tried recently has seemed to be comparable to AWS but it's just easier to set up since everything is managed through the same UI.

ScatterSpoke is in active development.  It provides a way to enter anonymous cards on a retro board.  It's fairly basic but gets the job done.  It's free and was created by someone we have worked with personally, so we have a feedback loop with the designers to suggest new features.  You can create teams and collect data in advance.  You can also accomplish grouping of cards and dot voting.
Kendo UI has a very large set of UI controls and it is easy to incorporate any of the controls into your application; however, it can be very difficult to customize and can sometimes be unresponsive.

Rust has many access/ownership and concurrency safety constructs as first-class members of the language. Strong typing and compile time safety assertions make it a good choice where exception-less runtime behavior is required.
https://trunkbaseddevelopment.com

Looks like a very nice option to use for remote retrospectives and story mapping. Very nice to be able to save all data as a private team to return to it later. Some might not like having to create yet another account somewhere, but there are advantages to that as well.

Rust has many access/ownership and concurrency safety constructs as first-class members of the language. Strong typing and compile time safety assertions make it a good choice where exception-less runtime behavior is required.

Compared with other low-level system programming languages (eg C) the tooling leaves something to be desired - chief problem being a lack of a debugger & good IDE support - but the modern features, strong typing and safety might well outweigh those concerns.

Rust has many access/ownership and concurrency safety constructs as first-class members of the language. Strong typing and compile time safety assertions make it a good choice where exception-less runtime behavior is required. Tool-chain lacks maturity but is improving.  Lack of easy access to OS-level libraries and kernel space limits it as a system programming language, but it does play well with C.
Easy to set up and run.  Reporting was the only negative (I just tracked results manually and did my own data trending) but the documentation claims there are easy ways to integrate reporting.
Simple to add test cases and categorize.  You can add and execute test runs plus assign sections to users.  Clear results and reporting.  Very friendly UI compared to Test Link.

Allows you to write asynchronous commands in a synchronous way.  It also manages the Selenium session for you.  Used for desktop web testing then integrated with BrowserStack automation to run tests across multiple mobile os/browser platforms.

Nice board. Allows login for facilitator to save the boards but doesn't require everyone on the team to register for an account. Can sort cards by time created or votes. Easy to use and edit. iOS and Android apps available.

I was exposed to Meteor during a code review project. Frontend and backend are very closely coupled making testing difficult. Seems to have problems scaling. You are limited to using a Mongo DB, but that may be abstracted in the future. It has gone through multiple phases of best practices in a short period of time, so various projects have become fragmented over time.   Main use for Meteor in my eyes is prototyping. You can spin up a simple app very quickly. Suggest holding off on this to see if it matures and gains more adoption.
It's a lot better than scaffolding things by hand, and it's better than having to deal with creating your own Grunt/Gulp configuration that your team is unlikely to maintain.
Not bad to work with, we needed to use it due to external library dependencies. It has the problems of JavaScript, which some people don't care for and some people are fine with.
Great way to do a lot of good things, including putting robust TLS on your service endpoints.
The disruption involved is pretty high. For someone like me who takes a little while to become fully focused on a problem it's killer.
Spent some more time with RoR lately, still think it's a Hold due to scaling issues
The easiest part of configuring a RoR server. If you're really trying to address the hard problem of scaling though and you CAN be thread-safe, consider using Puma
You do not like it, so you say, try it, try it and you may. Try it and you may I say." -- Sam-I-Am

Save yourself hours when prototyping -- use Bootstrap and its many built in UI components to quickly set up a responsive grid, style common web components like buttons, radio boxes, dropdowns or tables, and give your website common components like tab controls, navigation bars, custom modals, image galleries, off-canvas screens or menus, etc.
Out of the box WebSockets communication in your app with 1 line of code....yes please.
Literally a lifesaver when it comes to deploying an app to beta testers, crash reporting, analytics, etc..

Kotlin itself is a joy to work with, being a lot less verbose than Java and very compatible with it. The tooling is not quite up to par with Java, yet (refactorings are missing, like Inline Method, and some random compile or test failures).
I love seeing all the portals on Chell, helps me feel connected to all the remote Asynchrony teams on a daily basis!
Great if you're on an Apple device but we are all Linux / Android on our team.
Perch is dead. Long live Chell!

Very impressive and quite similar to the old Perch app, which made it very easy for me to figure out. I like the periodic photos that are taken automatically. But I also like the feature that allows me to retake a photo. It caught me yawning recently but I took the photo again and nobody was the wiser.

I'm not currently on a team where it's valuable as I don't have much need to remotely communicate with others.  I've gotten so used to not having a solution like this that I've forgotten how nice it is.  I haven't personally connected with it, so I'm not sure how well it works, but I think it's important for people to try it out if they even kind of need something like it.
This is an open source tool that needs some work.  At this point (03/17) it is very clunky.  You can not move cards from one column to another, you can only Delete or edit.

Sticky note board that is useful for vision diagrams, and other sticky-related uses.  Not too useful for teams unless you pay for the license.  Without the license you get 2 free boards at a time which has met my needs.  You can export your board to PDF and print it and hang it on the wall for your team to see.  There is overhead in learning to use it though, so I wouldn't use it for remote retros.  So I vote "Adopt" for Product related uses, and I vote "Meh" for retrospective uses.
I have used this a few times and all parties involved had a good experience.
The performance gains over Entity Framework are immense. Plus its easy to use and allows finer grain control.
The world of web development changes every day. Yes Angular gets the job done, but maybe something else gets it done better.
Easy to use and just makes sense.
Do you hate it when things work as expected? Then you'll love select2!
I've used this before, and generally it seems to work decently as a way to capture information from multiple people at the same time.
The de-facto standard for cloud based productivity software
Great private storage of documents to share with other WWT employees.

We use this in our project and our QA writes these tests with the client's input. We use the javascript version of this to behavior test an API we don't have control over but that our app must interface with and the iOS version (cucumberish) to drive the UI of our app. The javascript version has been easy to use and has provided us with quite a lot of value (including reports we can share with the client)

There are some limitations. Although, I cannot customize as much as what I would like, I still like it better than powerpoint for presentations because I can throw them together very quickly and they look really professional. The only negative is that the "sway" cannot be exported to any other format and lives in your sway account. Although others can edit it, you cannot transfer ownership or copy it to another Office 365 account. This limits its use for content that you want to persist should someone leave the company. Office 365 Admins can transfer ownership though. I plan on using it for interactive reports that customers see since I can display charts/metrics, etc from other Office 365 apps and the 'sway' will automatically update when the content is updated.

It takes a little while to get set up if you're integrating with a lot of 3rd party libraries. However, once everything is in place all the strongly typed goodness that TypeScript gives you is fantastic. Some of the features like Classes, Interfaces, and Generics give it the power and type safety of more sophisticated OOP languages.
I like it because it is easy to use and chat with team members in different locations.
Why do I need three keys for shortcuts that I could do with two on a PC.

A tool that I have used in the past (that isn't too cheesy - sorry agile coaches) is a quadrant system. One axis is the control axis (in my control, out of my control) and the other axis is the difficulty of change (easy to change or low hanging fruit and difficult to change). Then place all your complaints on the graph. Tackle more of the things that are in the in your control and easy to change, and try to make progress towards the others. Or consider pain that issue is causing.
www.funretrospectives.com

I've used Mongo in the past when I was working for a startup. It was my first time using NOSQL databases and I've got to admit it was a really good experience. As other people have stated, it depends on the app that you are trying to build...Mongo is pretty useful for real time apps.
Quite simply, this is the premier video chat program for communicating between Asynchrony offices.
The GitHub project: https://github.com/funretro/distributed

Spring Boot is great. Very, very well documented. Deployable to anything that runs Java (so, anything). Lots of nice ready-baked solutions for things like session management, ORM tools, authorization/authentication, etc. You just start a spring project and add these dependencies to your maven / gradle file and you'll probably spend just a few hours getting everything else set up.

I've used this approach for years and find a lot of value in it.  You see this approach more in ongoing development projects which may explain why more people at Asynchrony haven't used it since we do so much new development.  The Hive team has been using it the past 4 months for major features.

I found Kanbanize to be a bit clunky, though I didn't mind that much. What was worse is that, at least the way we had it configured, very noisy, making it hard to digest the state of the board or changes to cards.
Aside from a few UI kinks, I've found Trello to be significantly more pleasant to use than Kanbanize, approaching the level of Mingle.

This tool is great for auto collecting metrics.  It is a little clunky for adding pairs to a card to show whose working on it, but that's easy to work around with some custom properties (if you want that).  Like all tools, it takes some getting used to, but this tool excels at collecting a number of lean metrics automatically (e.g. cycle time).  It does have a mobile companion app, but it only shows a swimlane/queue at a time, so it's hard to see the state of the board.

Very flexible and easy to get up and running quick.  The mobile app is particularly good.  We use this for Springfield office management and I've used on delivery teams as well.  It requires an external tool to extract metrics (TKAT) but I believe some people here have set that up and it seems to be meeting their needs.

The functionality is somewhat limited out of the box.  As noted by others, adding pairs, changing status, etc is "clunky".  I liked the simplicity of using kanbanize sans those features.  It has a card templating feature which was handy.

Trello is simple and highly customizable.  To really be useful you will need some chrome extensions to hide lists and to show the card numbers for instance.  Urls to specific cards are not as intuitive as I would like them to be but that's a personal preference thing.

Cucumberish itself isn't anything special. I don't have any particular complaints per se however XCodeUITests which it has to integrate with are awful. They don't provide the fully fledged out functionality you need to accomplish most of the behavior driven tests written in gherkin and parsed with Cucumberish. Cucumberish also weirdly doesn't seem to completely fill out it's JSON report (although most of what's needed is there). It dumps it's report somewhere deep in the simulator however, making it difficult to extract them.

This tool is great for getting easy metrics around cycle time and forecasting.  It has nice options for creating different classes of service through swim lanes or card types.  It also does a decent job of creating card links when you want to roll a group of cards into a larger feature.  It sometimes has issues with keeping up to date unless you are connected all the time to the internet.  So if you run it on a laptop and put it in your bag while others make changes, you need to refresh the page.  It also only allows one person to be assigned to a card, which is annoying for pairing.  Adding multiple cards is not as easy as Trello, but this tool strikes a good balance between power and simplicity.

Definitely the most simple tool for visualizing work.  Easy to add multiple cards at a time or even columns.  I have never liked that I need to add browser plugins and put stuff on top of it to get the information that I want.  It not having lanes to show classes of service, WIP limits, or any type of metrics built in limits this as a kanban tool.  Great for very simple projects, but seems to fall over without looking for a lot of plugins or addons.
Steep learning curve but pays dividends quickly

Beautifully elegant tool. I'm about to use it to record demo snippets for a LnL presentation I'm preparing and I have a feeling I may never go without it for future presentations. Would also be really good for quickly and painlessly sharing terminal/vim protips, bug reproducers, etc with your colleagues.
Eris has successfully used Dapper as an improvement on top of raw ADO.net for our functional testing.
Avengers is using Vue.js on our learning project.

As a person that has used Kanbanize, Trello, and Mingle.  Trello has been a kanban tool that is very comparable to Mingle with ease of use and great functionality even though I have only been using it for about 3 to 4 weeks now.  I would highly recommend using Trello as kanban tool.

I used the tool for around 3 months, and it wasn't very user friendly when it came to quickly removing/adding people to a story.  Also, the application wasn't very reactive to show up-to-date transitions for the entire team without having the browser auto refresh every so often.

We've been very successful using Kotlin with our Android project.  It makes the code much more concise and is generally easier to work with.  It's really an incredible language.  Tooling isn't quite as good as Java, but the convenient language features make up for it.

Not the right tool for every job but is still and may always be the right tool for some. Definitely should consider using if you're writing anything you want to be very portable (both to different architectures and languages) and/or systems programming.
Fantastic when it "just works", but we've run into some edge cases where it just blows up with little explanation as to why.
I have some issues with it, but overall it is very helpful for quickly integrating libraries and sharing across teams.

Very useful for when you just need a place to POST to and/or the ability to see what was POSTed. For example, we have used this to get dummy URLs for a callback API while we were testing and didn't care about it, but the API would yell at us if the URL it tried to hit didn't return a 200.

Nice tool, MQL provides the ability to mine data and create nice visualizations. I haven't used the API extensively, but it is pretty open in terms of what you can do with it. I haven't compared it to other tools in a while, but generally I think the feature set is greater with Mingle, although setup can be more difficult than something like Trello.

Once we figured out how we wanted to do this it made it pretty easy to help standardize the build process across iOS teams. It also provides a ton of features we don't use such as automating the process all the way up to taking screenshots of your application and deploying to the appstore or to testflight.
Great for new ideas!  Lets you mix and match opening activities, gathering feedback activities and fun ways for generating insights.

There are currently a lot of external dependencies to getting things working for your team, but there are also a lot of people who know how to use pretty complex tools. See our research on launching a vApp from the portal: https://gitlab.asynchrony.com/proj-1301/iot-platform-research-and-development/wikis/home

Methods of "keeping someone in the loop" could be having a daily standup with them or when a turn around is called, asking the team if that person should be included. It was extremely helpful in ensuring team cohesion and the person whose responsibility it was changed throughout the project depending on what work was being done. We did this "mirroring" technique with architects, the PO, UX, and other developers.
I love Moq. Moq makes me happy. You can use it to do stubs too when that's what you really need, so don't let the name fool you.
If you just need a kanban board and some metrics, JIRA is probably overkill and you have other options that will probably have less of a learning curve.

Not an IDE, and my attempts to make it behave like an IDE via extensions have been frustrating - but still a great editor. With extensions, it has excellent language/framework support for syntax highlighting and intellisense.
Tried to test our Vue.js project with this. Immediately ran into problems that required hooking down into Selenium for. May be good for basic testing, but we found it to be insufficiently powerful.

Great lightweight editor. Atom felt sluggish to me so I moved to using VS Code (on a Mac) and have been quite pleased with it. It's been quite responsive and the intellisense/syntax highlighting works well. Nice set of plugins available and the integrated terminal is nice. This is my go-to editor at home.
Have only used it so far via Spring Data Redis. It seems to be a pretty simple and quick in-memory data store, but have not evaluated it at scale.

Avengers was using Vue.js on a learning project.  It is flexible and easy to learn and setup.  With limited support for (good) e2e testing javascript frameworks we used selenium in .NET to run our user acceptance tests.  The learning curve for Webpack (not "required" for vue but highly recommended) provided the most challenges.
The learning curve is significant and webpack setup can vary from project to project.  We used a generator for our vue project and edited it manually.
There are newer frameworks that are more efficient now.  I would not consider this for a new project.

Coby Utter and Matt Deckard have started using this while writing tests for "WealthCentral" and it is pretty nifty. It basically gives you all of the features you would expect from a full-fledged mocking framework like Moq or Mockito. Adding the Run Script phase is a one time cost that is quite painless.
Really great tool for easy access to test heuristics with the right-click of a mouse.
I have used it in multiple statistics courses.  Relatively easy to learn.  Widely used, so it's easy to find answers to questions.
Real life pairing is just so much better
Now that I'm no longer going to be adding articles, I recommend Avoid, as it just won't be the same without me!

We have many options for collaborating on stuff, Matthew Philip definitely believes in this one the most. There is a ton of old information to peruse on here on the history of Asynchrony and how hard we try to improve and adapt. I think it's a great resource.

Pros: Better at handling code-signing than Jenkins. Less moving parts than Jenkins so less opportunities for mistakes  Cons: Difficult / impossible to configure the way you specifically want to. If you find yourself wanting to do more than "just build" or maybe "just archive" you're in for a bad time.
Work slower for less quality
One slightly annoying thing I just ran into: it does not support mocking singletons, or any class that has no public initializers (i.e. a class that can only be constructed via factory methods)
